abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory, and
            sustainability is likely. However, while objectives
            surpassed expectations in terms of establishing the legal,
            and regulatory framework, major issues are still pending:
            competitiveness will occur only after successful completion
            of transaction award licenses for the new cellular, and
            wireless local loop service providers; urban areas'
            competitiveness should be parallel to the introduction of
            private participation in the provision of rural services,
            and based on a competitive tendering process; and, new
            impetus should be given to the Nepal Telecommunications
            Corporation (NTC). The lessons suggest that since radical
            sector reforms are time consuming, the continued involvement
            in the sector provides the Bank with the opportunity for a
            strong support to reform. Furthermore, labor unions should
            be involved at the early stages, to properly address their
            concerns, and avoid later resistance to change. The
            acceptance by the Bank of NTC's investment plan, -
            prior to the Government's agreement to pursue a
            privatization strategy - was later used by NTC as an issue
            to delay reforms, prevent competition, and, maintain its
            monopoly. Therefore, lending should have been contingent to
            the demonstrated firm commitment from main stakeholders,
            and, the processing of the Credit, contingent on Government
            ownership of the reform process.

18156025.trustfund: TF026625-FINANCING OF A MANAGEMENT SPECIALIST,TF020430-AUSTRIAN CONSULTANT TRUST FUND,TF032201-NEPAL - TELECOMMUNICATIONS,TF033105-NEPAL - TELECOMMUNICATIONS,TF020350-DANISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND
18156025.majtheme: Rural development,Urban development,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The project aims to expand
            telecommunications facilities and provide new services,
            improve the quality of existing services, strengthen the
            Nepal Telecommunications Corporation (NTC) and address major
            sector organization issues.  It will provide about 60,850
            net additional telephone lines, expand national and
            international long distance facilities, and engage
            consultants to strengthen NTC and address sector
            organization issues.  It will benefit all sectors of the
            economy through improved access to telecommunications
            facilities and improved service quality.  About 50,000 new
            subscribers will gain access to the network, which will
            provide a partial substitute for, and contribute to the
            overall efficiency of physical transportation.
